instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS IS PPBUS_G3H voltage after it has passed through a current sense resistor that supplies the TPS51980 and its associated buck converter with voltage to create the PP5V_S4 power rail..

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: I have this macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) it's my personal computer was working fine until one day I found it with fan spinning and black screen. I turn the macbook off and on again and there was no imagine on the screen and was looping on chime sound. Because I had issues before with this mac I decided to pull the bios chip from one board to the other. now the computer is turning on but no imagine. Theres any tutorial how I can flash a new cip?

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: I can tell you 100% there is nothing wrong with the ROM. Put back the original. Looping chime is usually a RAM or GPU issue.

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: with the other chip from the donor board is not doing any looping chime. I will put it back. where should I start troubleshooting?

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: There must be history to this machine, liquid I guess?

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: Yes I fix it it was working fine for over 3 months

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: Corrosion under RAM/SMC/CPU or anywhere else I bet.

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: I did a ultrasonic clean and nothing. Any suggestions? Should I do a reflow?

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: I cannot tell you where the corrosion is, you saw the original damage. Does it chime with the original BIOS back on it? Do NOT reflow if fully, just some flux and 150C heat should clear the crap under whatever chip the corrosion is under.

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: ok I found <RESISTOR>R6324</RESISTOR> with a missing cap. I did replace it now the machine is turning on only if is plugged to the battery and the charger if i take the board out and plug the charger it doesn't turn on

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V3_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.49V instead of 20V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 17V instead of 20V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41V when I took the measurements at l7095 the fan start to spin. i disconnect the power cable put it back on and again no fan spin
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> the voltage it's dropping slowly to 0 and its starts all over again
I'm really lost on this board

threads.title: macbook pro 2014 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) EFI
threads.message: You are using a non original or non 85W charger.
